title: east-lothians-six-childrens-hubs-close-summer-holidays
story: More than  staff helped support the hubs through the summer holidays after switching from their normal roles to support the emergency measures.East Lothian Council openedsix hubs across its main towns, reducing them to four during school holidays as required.The council said the hubs not only supported key workers and carers but also vulnerable children and those with complex needs.Staff from schools, nurseries, library services, countryside rangers and more offered to help run the hubs, providing for hundreds of youngsterswho attended.During the summer, senior pupils from secondary schools were also able to help out.Monica Patterson, council chief executive, said: ldquoIrsquod like to thank staff from across the council and our partners who did such a fantastic job in initially establishing and then maintaining the hubs, including provision during school holidays.ldquoI recognise that a huge amount of planning, preparation and day-to-day support has been provided and Irsquom pleased that this has benefited many families by enabling key worker parents and carers to continue working, while continuing to support children and young people with complex additional support needs.Councillor Shamin Akhtar, cabinet spokesperson for education and childrenrsquos services, said: ldquoI know that many parents and carers have valued the support provided by our childrenrsquos hubs since March.ldquoPutting emergency learning and childcare in place was incredibly supportive, and we couldnrsquot have done it without the hard work and commitment of so many staff from across a number of dferent teams and services across the council and from some of our partners.

title: children-left-without-water-school-rules-confusion
story: Confusion over new guidelines introduced across East Lothian schools as youngsters ed saw children in some schools told they could not refill their personal water bottles unless there was a tap in their classroom.It meant that by lunchtime on Wednesday, as temperatures soared into the mid s across East Lothian, a number of children had emptied their bottles.Parents took to social media with reports of primary school children collected from school parched and complaining of headaches after they were told they could not get more water.One mother revealed that her nine-year-old son was refused a chance to refill his bottle after running out of water in the morning and told he could not leave his desk, which was directly under a window with the sun streamingin.She said: "If this was a prison and inmates were refused access to water in the heat there would be an outcry, so why were our children treated like this "Campaigning group Us For Them Scotland later named three East Lothian schools - Musselburgh Grammar School, Haddington Primary School and Campie Primary School in Musselburgh -among a list of Scottish schools where there had been complaints about children being refused access to water.East Lothian Council said that access to water was available in all schools and schools had been given further clarication on the guidelines.A spokesperson said: "Access to drinking water is available in all of our schools."We are encouraging all families to send their child to school with a ready-filled water bottle ndash families were advised to contact their school in advancethere would be an issue providing one."Refill opportunities are available, with the most appropriate method having been determined by inidual schools to best meet their setting. This means all children have access to drinking water."Our schools have put a huge amount of work into a safefor all children and young people, and will continue to monitor how well their arrangements are working."We have worked with our schools to clary guidance and put in place measures that will make sure all children and young people have opportunities to top-up drinking water throughout the day."Parents on social media said their children had also been unable to access water yesterday.One parentsaid: "This also happened to my son today, who came home and said he was so thirsty he felt light-headed."Another local added: "My two grandsons said the same when we picked them up, both were gasping on a drink. My daughters sending them with extra water bottles tomorrow."Other parents said that the problem occured at a number of schools, pointing out that some children attended breakfast clubs and after-school clubs, meaning even with an extra bottle they had to make it last for nine hours.Another asked of teaching staff: "If you can grab a takeaway latte from Costa, why cant they refill the wee ones water bottles "However, others defended the teaching staff, pointing out that emails to parents had made those whose children would not be able to refill water bottles during the day aware and that schools were "on a learning curve" with new ways of working.At Campie Primary School in Musselburgh, where concerns were also raised on Wednesday, it is understood that teachers went round the classrooms with jugs of fresh water in the afternoon and planned to do that again.Us For Them Scotland organiser Johannah Bisset said: "Even cattle have a legal right to water. Yet somehow our children have had that right stripped away from them.ldquoThis decision once again demonstrates the utter disregard these decision-makers have for the wellbeing of our children."Children all over Scotland are writing to the First Minister to ask her to provide water for all of Scotlandrsquos children. We have great hopes that she will respond positively to protect our children."

title: property-patter-give-home-facelift-budget---living-room-bedroom
story: But in part  of our lsquoHow to give your home a facelt on a budgetrsquo, wersquore going to give you some great ideas to update your bedrooms, living room and even hallway.BedroomsWhen it comes to styling your bedroom, the best way to inject some colour and style, whilst keeping costs down, is to add it through your accessories. Keep your wall colours neutral, like white and grey, but use your curtains, bedding and cushions to inject splashes of colour.Buying new bedding and hanging a new set of curtains can cost a lot less than a few tins of paint once you factor in all the rollers and brushes yoursquoll need to buy, plus it will take less time too.Once yoursquove bought the cushions, next time yoursquore thinking about changing the colour, just buy new covers and match the size of the cushions. That means you can store the others away, pass them on to a friend or use them in another room.Donrsquot forget about artwork. You can find some really trendy prints online and IKEA is great for cheap frames too. Make sure you buy the same size prints each time, meaning you can keep the same frames. You can update the frames easily too with a cheap can of spray paint.Canrsquot afford a new carpet  Yoursquoll be amazed at what a good deep clean and adding a colourful or patterned rug can do.If your furniture is looking a bit tired, upcycle with a lick of paint and new door handles. You can pick up a tin of furniture paint from most hardware stores or online and you can buy cute, quirky doorknobs from eBay or Etsy, or even just try spray painting the existing ones.Metal accessories like curtain rods and light fittings can benefit from that spray paint too!Upcycling is a great way to keep costs low, give a much loved item a new lease of le and is good for the environment by cutting out waste.Living roomMoving on to the most used room in the house, this can be the most dficult to update as it no doubt has many uses. From the TV room to the playroom to the dining room, your living space probably needs to be more practical than anything . But you can still add some style along the way.Your sofa likely dominates the room and can be the most expensive piece in the room ndash with the exception of the TV! So replacing this often can be costly. But have you considered replacing the covers  If your sofa is in generally good condition but itrsquos looking a bit off-colour, you can buy covers that fit over the top.IKEA do a range of these covers that are made for their sofa ranges, but you can find places online that offer made to measure services. This can be more expensive, but definitely cheaper than buying a whole new sofa and are machine washable! Alternatively, adding a new throw and some scatter cushions can have the same effect.Many of the tips for the bedroom can be used in the living room too. Like adding a nice feature wall for a splash of colour or why not try adding a nice gallery wall with lots of family pictures  A great way to add a personal touch to a room. You can even get the family involved to pick out their favourite pictures.Plants are a great way to brighten up a room and fill any unused corners. Donrsquot worry, it doesnrsquot mean another mouth to feed, there are plenty of really great looking fake ones to buy.Have you tried shopping from other rooms in your house  Yoursquod be surprised at how much you can change your rooms by simply swapping the accessories about.HallwayTherersquos nothing nicer than a warm welcome so donrsquot forget your hallway when yoursquore giving your home a makeover.If itrsquos on the small size then good advice is to keep it nice and bright to give the illusion of space and add colour by adding some prints to the wall, some useful hanging hooks and even a funky doormat.Everything in your hallway needs to have a practical use, but that doesnrsquot mean it has to be boring.You can add plants here too butyoursquore limited on floor space, why not try some hanging baskets or small potted plants on shelves.Maybe go the extra mile and paint the doors in your hallway  This trend is becoming more popular, with people opting for painting their doors and skirting boards, from pink to yellow and even black.Hopefully, these tips have given you some DIY inspiration to give your home a little low-cost makeover.

title: online-edinburgh-festival-12-must-see-shows-events
story: Thats exactly what has happened.You cant generally hit pause and play at the same time, but the Edinburgh Festival has managed it for its  iteration, with a rich, brave and pioneering programme of mostly digital and online events with here and there a visual treat for capital residents and those tourists who have decided to come anyway.The theatres may be dark but, as the programme makes clear, the artistic light burns bright regardless.My Light Shines On DisplayAs well as being the umbrella title for much of the digital offering from this yearrsquos Edinburgh International Festivalndash Kirsty Wark fronts the programme, which features a performance by Scottish Chamber Orchestra cellist Su-a Lee ndash My Light Shines On is also a light display project which will illuminate the cityrsquos famous festival venues.Using beacons of light which will be visible from vantage points across the capital it has been created by Scottish lighting designers Kate Bonney and Simon Hayes, the duo behind Pitlochryrsquos Enchanted Forest and the Electric Glen in East Renfreshire.The inspiration is the tradition of the so-called lsquoghost lightrsquo in which a light is left on in a theatre even when the venue is lsquodarkrsquo, as all theatres currently are. Andyoursquore wondering about where title came from, itrsquos a line from Primal Screamrsquos  song Movinrsquo On Up.www.e whats-on  mylightshinesonDeclanA companion piece, of sorts, to the Traverse Theatrersquos  hit Mouthpiece, written by Kieran Hurley and a keen dissection of class and culture in the capital.Here, Mouthpiece actor Lorn Macdonald turns director to re-work the two-hander in order to concentrate on the character he played, the titular Declan, a -year-old aspiring artist.Using footage shot on the Edinburgh streets plus animation and elements of the Mouthpiece script, he fleshes out Declanrsquos le and experiences. The resulting film forms part of the Traverse Digital Festival  and will be available to watch on demand later in the month.From August www.traverse declanEdinburgh International Book FestivalThe Booker Prize-winning author of Girl, Woman, Other recently became the first British woman of colour to top the UK paperback fiction chart and in the wake of the murder of George Floyd therersquos a sharp topicality to her novel, which follows the lives of  mostly black women across the years.In this special event, to be broadcast from the Edinburgh International Book Festivalrsquos Edinburgh studio, she discusses her work with the First Minister, who has written warmly about Eisto and is no stranger to the book festival  herself. Doubtless there will also be some chat about the topic occupying Ms Sturgeonrsquos time during her day job, the ongoing public health emergency caused by coronavirus.The event is free to watch online though registration is required for anybody who wants to ask a question through the QAor to participate in the chatroom. Andyou miss the event, it and most of the many other author events will remain online for the duration of the book festival.August , .pmwww.edbookfestLes Amazones DrsquoAfrique: A Virtual Live PerformanceAn lsquoas liversquo gig by musical powerhouse Les Amazones DrsquoAfrique, the multi-lingual, politically conscious all-female collective who blend hip-hop and RB with the traditional sounds of their Malian homeland.A bona fide supergroup ndash a founding member is Mariam Doumbia of Amadou  Mariam, and regular helpmates include the great Angeacutelique Kidjo ndash the band released their second album, Amazones Power, to great acclaim earlier this year and are bringing through an army of young talent in their wake.Part of the My Light Shines On strand, you can watch the band on the EIFrsquos dedicated YouTube channel from .pm on August .August  onwardswww.youtube user edinburghintfestivalEdinburgh Art FestivalEdinburghrsquos thoroughfares will this year bedevoid of crowds, buskers and whatever you call those people who persistently thrust flyers under your nose, but the special vibe of the festival streets is being re-created to an extent by an array of outdoor interventions from the Edinburgh Art Festivalas part of its Around The City strand.EAF favourite Peter Liversidge has recreated his  project Flags For Edinburgh ndash  flags saying HELLO will fly from buildings across the capital ndash and where there are billboard-mounted artistic interventions both whimsical and political. Keep your eyes peeled.Various venueswww.edinburghartfestivalFringe On FridayRunning on Fridays throughout what would have been the Edinburgh Fringe, this paid-for,  minute iety style show-cum-fundraiser gives you a slice of what might have been.The virtual curtain goes up at pm, tickets cost poundand among the acts confirmed so far are David OrsquoDoherty, Lost Voice Guy and Tf Stevenson.From August www.edfringeChamber Music Soundscapes In Princes Street GardensEvery weekday at pm from Monday the EIF will mount a live concert featuring a range of top chamber musicians, the only dference from normal festival fare being that the musicians will be in The Hub, EIFrsquos headquarters at the top of the Royal Mile, and the audience will be in Princes Street Gardens listening via an array of speakers .Among the musicians lined up to play are members of the BBC Scottish Symphony Orchestra , the Elias String Quartet , the Dunedin Consortand, kicking things off on Monday, tenor Nicky Spence and pianist Malcolm Martineau performing Shakespearean Songs. As ever, you can watch on the EIF YouTube channel.August -, Princes Street Gardenswww.e whats-on  chambermusicprincesstreetgardenswww.youtube user edinburghintfestivalDouglas StuartShuggie Bain, Douglas Stuartrsquos searing tale about a desolate childhood in Thatcherrsquos Glasgow, has been longlisted for the Booker Prize ndash not bad for a debut novel, even one which took its author  years to complete.Here, the Glasgow-born writer and former menswear designer talks to fellow Scot Damian Barr about growing up gay on a Glasgow housing scheme, his unlikely hero Shuggie Bain and the prospect of literary fame.Featuring as part of the Edinburgh International Book Festivalrsquos Made In Scotland series, the event is free to watch online though registration is required for anybody who wants to ask a question through the QAor to participate in the chatroom.August , .pmwww.edbookfestGhost LightScreening as part of the EIFrsquos My Light Shines On strand, this collaborative film by Edinburgh-based director Hope Dickson Leach and the National Theatre of Scotlandrsquos artistic director Jackie Wylie features a cast which includes James McArdle, Siobhaacuten Redmond, Thierry Mabonga and Anna Russell-Martin.Described as a love letter to Scottish theatre it draws on work by writers such as JM Barrie, David Greig, Rona Munro and Jackie Kay, as well as original compositions story: Here we look at some of the businesses who will no longer be operating in the city and the ones under threat.Remnant KingsCity location: Howard StreetA total of  stafflost their jobs from the firmrsquos bases in Glasgow, Hamilton, and Edinburgh after the administrators were called in.The firm, which started in Glasgow in , said that although they were historically profitable, they have since suffered from declining turnover and trading dficulties in recent years caused by changing consumer habits.:Glasgow firm Remnant Kings goes into admistration resulting in job lossesOasis and Warehouse GroupCity locations past and present: Buchanan Galleries, Silverburn, Princes Square, and Glasgow Fort.The company behind Oasis and Warehouse went into administration in April when Deloitte was appointed as administrator.All stores haveclosed indefinitely whileonline sales have stopped.Reports say the fashion brands have been sold to restructuring business Hilco in a deal which includes stock but not the  stores or  concessions.Hash Ladha, chief executive of Oasis Warehouse, previouslysaid: ldquoThis is a situation that none of us could have predicted a month ago, and comes as shocking and dficult news for all of us.ldquoWe as a management team have done everything we can to try and save the iconic brands that we love.:Oasis and Warehouse who have shops in Glasgow fall into administrationCath KidstonCity location: Gordon StreetCath Kidston said they will not reopen their shops when lockdown ends.They called in the administrators in April with the closure of shops costing around  jobs.It is understood that the owner of the retro fashion brand has secured a deal to buy back the brand and its online operation. title: recipe-mary-continis-bottom-fridge-summer-omelette
story: BOTTOM OF THE FRIDGE SUMMER OMELETTE- spears of asparagus organic courgettes tablespoons olive oil and a blob of butter large free-range eggsg full flavoured cheese: Pecorino, Parmigiano, Mull cheddarHandful each of flat leaf parsley and fresh mint, finely choppedSea salt and black pepperMETHODPrepare the asparagus. Snap the stem where it naturally breaks and set aside the stalks .Trim the spears and cut them in half wise. Pot in boiling salted water for  minutes and drain.Wash and cut the courgettes into thin slices.Warm the oil and butter in a heavy bottomed frying pan.Add the courgettes in a single layer and sauteacute over a high heat until they are softened and browned at the edges.Add the drained asparagus.Season.Beat the eggs in a large bowl and season.Mix in half of the grated cheese and the chopped parsley.Pour the mixture over the sauteacuteed vegetables.Let the bottom of the omelette set and start to brown, tipping the frying pan so that the egg gently cooks.As soon as the bottom is set add the mint leaves and use a spatula to fold the eggs over and sprinkle with the last of the grated cheese.Cook for a further  minutes to form a large fluffy cushion.SUMMER LEAF SALADInstead of buying ready-made bags of salad leaves, make your own salad mixture. Buy a selection of whole lettuce, enes and radicchio. Pull of some leaves of each and wash well in salted water making sure you rinse off any grit.Add some slices of spring onions, radishes, cucumber, and red onion to add crunch and tartness.A few leaves of fresh herbs add a refreshing burst of flavour: rocket, mint, tarragon, marjoram all grow easily in the garden or on the window ledge.Dressing is easy: sea salt,  parts olive oil and a squeeze of lemon juice.You can keep small bags of prepared leaves ready in the fridge in plastic bags for up to three days, ready to dress as required.

title: Opinion  Iain Macwhirter  All shall have prizes in the great exams U-turn     except John Swinney
story: Mr Swinney cast aside the independent Scottish Qualications Authority and their wretched algorithms, and restored the very estimated exam grades which he, and the First Minister, Nicola Sturgeon had said only last week were ldquonot credible.All upgraded results will stand all , downgraded results will be reversed. Everyone wins. And all shall have prizes.:IndyRef: New poll shows % would back independence as SNP set for record Holyrood majorityMind you, I dont think Mr Swinney will be interfering in many future examinations. I cant think of any ministerial U-turn that has been quite as humiliating as this one. Not least because Mr Swinney spent half of his statement defending the very moderation system that he had just discarded.No serious government can conduct its business in this way. Mr Swinney gave no principled explanation of why he was abandoning the work of the supposedly independent SQA ndash other than that a number young people felt that the system was unjust. That is undeniably true and we all felt for them.But this capitulation leaves the SQA in an impossible position, and brings the whole examination process into question. Indeed, I dont see how the SQA can continue in its present form. Certainly, it cannot conduct its normal moderation of exam results with any confidence in future years.And nor can Mr Swinney. He must surely go now, after this fiasco, and without delay. Someone must come in to restore respect for the standards in Scottish education and serve the last rites on the Qualications Authority.Indeed, standardised assessment through competitive examinations looks to have had its day. As Mr Swinney hinted, it has become increasingly unpopular in recent years. Though every country including Finland, the leading edge of pedagogical progressivism, uses objective testing.But after this fiasco, examinations like the Highers will surely lose their unique status and will likely be supplanted by teacher estimates of ability which, according to Mr Swinney, is the most reliable way to gauge academic achievement. This, even though he himself concedes that in the past teacher assessment has been no reliable guide to exam performance.The impact on grade inflation will be as the First Minister herself forecast last week ldquoincredible. A % increase in Highers grades means that this years students will forever be marked out as the year when exam credibility went out the window.Whoever called the process by which the Scottish Qualication Authority adjusts exam scores to reflect past school performance ldquomoderation had a dry sense of humour. It has caused fury amongst teachers, pupils, parents.The anger shows no sign of moderating even after Swinneys desperate attempt to put a lid on the worst exam crisis in  years. This was a statement that was as humiliating as it was self-contradictory.:UK falls into recession after lockdown sees record contractionHe began by explaining atwhy the moderation applied by the SQA did not disproportionately downgrade students from deprived areas, as has been widely claimed. This is because the grade inflation, against historic standards, was higher in schools in these areas, at %, than in schools in more prosperous areas, which inflated by only around %. Greater moderation was therefore applied out of fairness, not classism.He then commended the SQAs ldquoopen and transparent adjustment methodology and insisted that it was ldquoin use throughout the UK and across the world". But, er, not in Scotland any more. Mr Swinney then let the algorithmic cat out of the bag by pointing out that exam moderation happens every year to some extent as the SQA, and its English equivalent Ofqual, manipulate grade boundaries. But not presumably in future.He even announced, solemnly, that the remit of the SQAwas to ensure that every student got ldquothe qualications they deserved. The teacher estimates: ldquo awarded without moderation, he said ldquo would have led to an increase in pass rates without precedent.Sothe methodology was so fair and robust, why was he over-ruling the independent SQA and allowing this unprecedented grade inflation to take place  Well, Mr Swinney had spoken to young people who felt ldquotheir future was being determined by statistical modelling. The credibility of exam grades was of secondary importance to ldquothe risk that people would lose faith in the system. Well, they certainly will now.But does anyone seriously think that the SQA actually marked down working class students because they were living in a deprived postcode  Of course not. The SQA anyway subjected its moderation regime to an Equalities Impact Assessment ndash as it is obliged to do ndash before it published them.Moderation by algorithm is a pretty blunt instrument and doesnt take account of inidual performance. But, as Mr Swinney says, it is very widely used. Capitulating to grade inflation of up to % may win political points in the short term, but it will store up big problems for the future.:John Swinneys SQA U-Turn: Seven things you need to knowEvery year, grade boundaries move up and down to ensure fairness and comparable outcomes. Tens of thousands of pupils have their exam results routinely moderated. The English equivalent of the SQA, Ofqual, uses a very similar ldquostandardisation model against which to correct scores which depart from the historical average.Englands pandemic moderation is, according to reports, even greater than ours ndash % of grades have been adjusted downwards from the estimates provided by teachers, against % in Scotland. We wont know the final figures until tomorrowwhen the English A level results are unveiled. But, strangely, there has not been anything like the controversy over moderation that we have seen here.The inconvenient truth is that the Scottish ldquopandemic cohort, as they are already being dubbed, has exchanged one unfairness for another. They may have got the grades they and their teachers wanted, but those grades will forever be tainted by the chaotic and unprincipled way in which they were awarded. Handed to them by an Education Secretary in panic mode who said he had no right to interfere in examination results. And then proceeded to do just that.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald.

title: five-new-albums-listen-week
story: DREAMLANDThe latest showing from electronic indie four-piece Glass Animals is a psychedelic trip down memory lane, with bass-heavy beats and introspective lyrics.Dreamland is the bands third studio album and combines their distinctive electro-pop sound with influences ranging from the Beach Boys to Timbaland.Frontman Dave Bayley says inspiration for the album came at a time of "confusion and uncertainty" , when he found it easier to look to the past rather than the future.The popular single Heatwaves, released in June, is a prime example of such reflection - with lyrics perfectly capturing the feel of obsessive young relationships: Sometimes all I think about is you  Late nights in the middle of June.Big electronic drum beats feature throughout the album but a whimsical, nostalgic vibe creeps in through lighter synths and twanging guitar on the title track Dreamland, and Melon And The Coconut.A standout track is Your Love , released back in February, which pays tribute to the production styles of Justin Timberlake and Missy Elliot with its driving beat and dance-y melody.As well as being rammed with enormous tunes, the wistful, throwback lyrics make Dreamland an apt and strong contender for one of the major sounds of an unconventional summer.Mike BediganMADE OF RAINTHE PSYCHEDELIC FURSMade Of Rain, the first album from The Psychedelic Furs in  years, proves the new wave darlings havent lost their edge.In recent years the group have reformed on a semi-regular basis to play live dates.But they said they had begun to "feel like a jukebox" and set about writing new material to bolster their sets.The Furs sported a rotating line-up throughout the s, anchored by the presence of brothers Richard and Tim Butler.They released a cluster of seminal records including s Mirror Moves but towards the end of the decade the quality began to drop off.Made Of Rain recaptures some of the heady glamour of their early albums, and a fair dose of their swagger.It is also a markedly darker affair ndash and thats saying something for the band that inspired The Horrors and Interpol.Pounding drums, soaring synths and brooding vocals are all present, but most importantly, the songs are just excellent.Alex GreenWASHED OUTPURPLE NOONA decade on from the heyday of the microgenre known as chillwave, Atlantas Ernest Greene s with his fourth album as Washed Out.Opening track Too Late sounds instantly familiar, mid-tempo, muffled vocals conveying a vague sense of unease and regret, s drums, washes of synths.With the shock of the new long gone, this laid-back, tasteful sound seems more like yacht rock than the cutting edge, and can easily blend into the background.Chillwave always tends to be described as summertime music, hazy and shimmering, and, listening during a heatwave, Purple Noon ticks all those boxes - the title comes from the sunbaked Mediterranean  film based on The Talented Mr Ripley.The single Time To Walk Away isfaster and insidiously catchy, the sort of earworm that re-emerges days later with you wondering what it is, and how it got there.But too many of the tracks struggle to hold the attention, with Greenes -year journey from scratchy lo-fi to polished textures inspired by Sade and Phil Collins ending in a bland cul-de-sac.Matthew GeorgeJON ANDERSON, HANDSJon Andersons latest solo album,you can call it that, has been a long time in the making.Originally conceived  years ago during a songwriting retreat in Calornias Big Bear Mountain area, the original tapes were left to languish in Andersons garage.But two years ago the co-founder and former lead singer of progressive rock pioneers Yes was approached by producer Michael Franklin who had enough capital to complete the project.Anderson recruited a bevvy of friends, admirers and personal heroes to work on the tracks, including Jethro Tulls Ian Anderson and pianist Chick Corea .It also features archive recordings from Andersons former Yes bandmates - drummer Alan White and bassist Chris Squire, the latter having died in  from a rare form of leukaemia.Theres prog-rock wig-outs in Activate and Come Up, while First Born Leaders delivers reggae rhythms with a hallucinogenic edge.Andersons brand of prog-rock, psychedelia and world music may no longer be cool, hip or even groovy, but his magnetic charm and free-wheeling musicality is enough to lend , Hands some weight.Alex GreenLAYLA KAYLIFLOVERS DONT MEETBritish singer-songwriter Layla Kayl draws on Shakespeare, the work of th century Persian poet Rumi and US country music on her latest album.Sound like a lot, right  But at seven tracks, Lovers Dont Meet is short and sweet.Kayls voice is warm and graceful and the guitar work simple and direct.Its a heady mix and one that benefits from the pleasing production she secured during recording sessions in Nashville with producer Jason Hall.Lovers Dont Meet pays homage to a genre Kayl has always loved, but it fails to replicate the soul or substance of true country music.Instead, Kayl fills up the album with references - to the queen of country Dolly Parton on Dont You Know Me Yet  and th century Syrian writer Nizar Qabbani on As I Am.The result is a little messy, but enjoyable nonetheless.Alex Green

title: agenda-business-needs-support-preventing-covid-spikes
story: AS Aberdeen residents and businesses weather the cityrsquos second lockdown, itrsquos time for fresh thinking on how we manage the Covid- challenge to protect public health and prevent further damage to the economy.Further lockdowns are devastating to peoplersquos livelihoods, destroying businesses and adversely impacting on any hope for a short-term economic recovery, and must be avoided at all cost. While the Scottish Government, which is ultimately responsible for safeguarding public health, has a major role to play, I believe businesses are better placed to make things happen and to do so far more quickly.The best way forward should involve a new approach with business taking the lead to implement greater safety measures with the support of government and other public sector bodies.This will start with business owners and managers stepping up and being more proactive in ensuring they operate within a safer framework to stop the spread of this virus. As well as providing a clean and safe environment for their customers at all times, they will also need to consider implementing other creative measures and better utilising existing technology.We are already seeing a number of examples of this across the globe where businesses are driving forward on-the-ground initiatives to reduce the risk of a further lockdown. Restaurants in Kinsale, in County Cork, Ireland have, for example, begun testing the temperatures of all their customers upon entry. Meanwhile Tourism Portugal has introduced ldquoSafe  Clean certication which enables participating hotels to provide the reassurance they have undertaken the appropriate level of disinfecting and have made hand sanitiser available to guests throughout their stay. Even McDonaldrsquos has gone beyond government guidelines by making the wearing of masks mandatory for all customers entering any of their , US restaurants.While businesses in Aberdeen and throughout Scotland should be taking the lead in bringing new and effective measures to fruition, the support of the Scottish Government will be essential as well as beneficial. Agencies including Scottish Enterprise, where we have made initial representations on this issue, could provide grants and other support measures. This could help many hard-pressed businesses put temperature monitoring devices for both staff and customers as well as other facilities in place at a time when the strain on their finances may otherwise prevent such expenditure. This would put even more pressure on the public purse, but it would be a sensible investmentit prevents the economic carnage that comes from further lockdowns.Nicola Sturgeonrsquos leadership has been solid throughout much of this pandemic. If she is serious about Scotland rebuilding its economy she should require business to take a greater role in proactively preventing the risk of further outbreaks of the pandemic but also provide the appropriate support to enable it to do this.Andrew Montague is CEO of ClearWater Hygiene

title: opinion-mark-smith-scotland-finally-something-inglorious-tradition
story: But could they be a threatened species  The Scottish Governmentrsquos Werritty report on grouse moors last year said that,there wasnrsquot a marked improvement in the populations of birds of prey on grouse moors , then a licensing system should be introduced. We await the Governmentrsquos response. This week Labour also called for the licensing of grouse shooting after a big increase in the illegal killing of birds during the lockdown.But in Scotland, Irsquom afraid, the signs of progress are not good. For a start, the Werritty report was based on the flawed premise that driven grouse shooting can be made acceptable. Werritty was explicitly looking for ways in which grouse moors could continue to be a part of the economy instead of questioning whether Scotlandrsquos countryside should tolerate a business that harms the countryside ndash through the burning of heather, for example.The reportrsquos conclusion on licensing also ended up being rather limp because the group that led the report was ided, which meant the compromise of suggesting a licensing systemthere is no improvement in bird of prey populations. Which gives the Scottish Government a get-out: wersquore waiting, theyrsquoll say, to seetherersquos been an improvement hellip still waiting hellip still waiting. The Government has also shown a lack of urgency in responding to Werritty. It does not look good.There are also serious question marks over whether licensing will work. First off, the people who are illegally killing birds of prey are unlikely to be deterred by a licensing systemtheyrsquore not deterred by the law as it stands Scotland for more than  years.Therersquos also a danger thatan ineffective licensing system will be introduced and then everything will just carry on as normal. I spoke to the conservationist Mark Avery about this recently and his view was that the whole idea of licensing depended on how robust the system was a weak one would pretty much allow the wildle criminals to carry on regardless.Some people in the shooting community feel theyrsquore being unfairly singled out over this. I remember speaking to one guy who runs a training school for gundogs who said he was frustrated that certain ways of killing animals ndash fishing for example ndash were seen as socially acceptable whereas shooting had a stigma attached to it. A farrier also told me that at least shooting enthusiasts are being honest about killing animals ndash townies on the other hand will happily tuck into burgers and fish and chips and yet judge people for shooting birds or deer.In some ways, I can see where the country sports enthusiasts are coming from on that one ndash for most of us, grouse shooting is a weird and distant practice and maybe that makes it easier to support moves to control it. But fishing doesnrsquot involve killing every other species in the water, whereas the ideal grouse moor from the point of view of landowners and gamekeepers is one thatrsquos devoid of any predator, which leads to predator control on a mass scale ndash legal and illegal.That is the key to the problem: a model that is effectively based on the killing of birds of prey. Perhaps licensing can do something to improve it. I hope so. Perhaps the Government will support licensing. I hope for that too. But it may be that it all rests on a simple question. Mark Thomas of the RSPB said this week that most of the bird of prey deaths theyrsquod seen during lockdown were linked in some way to shooting. So the question is: will licensing change the behaviour of those people  Or do we have to go further and ban driven grouse shooting completely Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald.

title: opinion-doug-marr-time-rethink-exam-system-ground
story: I donrsquot want to rain on the parade of the youngsters whose grades have been inflated, but colleges, universities and employers are always going to be sceptical about awards made in . I feel particularly sorry for this yearrsquos candidates who would have done well no matter which year they sat their exams, but whose  award will be forever tainted. Presumably next yearrsquos results will be back in line with previous years. If so, Higher pass rates in  will be around % lower than in , further undermining the credibility and value of this yearrsquos awards. Also, what about candidates in earlier years whose award was lower than their teachersrsquo estimates  I would like my physics award from  to be looked at again. If wersquore buying into the principle of teachersrsquo infallibility in estimating grades, there must be thousands out there with a legitimate cause for complaint. Oh, teachers are infallible for this year only, surely placing an even larger question mark over the  results. Additionally, has a precedent been created If, and itrsquos a big , this yearrsquos results mean anything at all, why have exams at all  The about-turn has been justied on the grounds that some pupils in lower performing schools have been disproportionately disadvantaged. That ignores the fact that these pupils, in these schools, are disadvantaged by the exam system every year. I worked in a school in a disadvantaged area where the staff went knocking on doors to get pupils to even turn up for their exams.Perhaps this years experience offers an opportunity to reconsider how we assess youngstersrsquo learning without sacricing the systemrsquos credibility.Predictably, the Education Secretaryrsquos political opponents have been quick to play to the gallery, but slower to say what they would have done. A Tory MSP even reinvented himself as a spokesman for ldquoour toughest communities. It will be interesting to hear his verdict on the very similar system of standardisation to be used in England.Politically, Mr Swinney may have taken the only option, but time will tellit was the correct decision for Scottish education and its exam system.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald.

title: agenda-seeking-green-transformative-recovery-scotland
story: THE Scottish Governmentrsquos economic recovery plan published last week initially gives you a feeling of deacutejagrave vu ndash another long government report including many announcements that we have seen before. There remains a widening gap between high-level rhetoric and delivery on the ground. However, there are a number of statements which suggest the government is beginning to give the necessary prominence to the role that investment in our natural environment can play in addressing the climate, nature and economic crises.In accepting the recommendations of its own Advisory Group on Economic Recovery, the Scottish Government is taking a new ldquofour capitals approach which involves viewing the economy through four pillars of economic, natural, human and social capital. Just as importantly, it is accepting the advice of the group ldquoto treat each pillar as equally important.Government recognises that improving our wellbeing is dependent on our ability to conserve and grow our natural assets. It also appears to have accepted the radical advice of the Scottish Infrastructure Commission that the next Infrastructure Investment Plan should have natural infrastructure as a key component.In other aspects the plan lacks urgency and clear time commitments. Much of the detail seems to have been left to the update of the Climate Change Plan and the Infrastructure Investment Plan. Sadly, a clear timetable is also lacking and all we are told is that there will be ldquoregular updates to the plan.There is welcome acknowledgement that investing in our natural environment, nature-based solutions and green skills are vital to address the twin climate and bioersity crises. Nonetheless, to be genuinely transformational government will need to go further than existing commendable commitments to peatland restoration and vague pledges of ldquowoodland expansion.Government must ensure that we also maintain our peatland in good condition, prevent further damaging extraction and horticultural use and invest in native woodland. Nature-based solutions must also go further and include investment in greening our cities and enhancing the marine environment.With the Scottish Budget already under signicant pressure, providing the necessary funding for nature-based solutions is going to be even more of a challenge. This cannot, however, be an excuse for further delay. Investment in our natural assets must get a fair share of the poundbn earmarked for infrastructure plans. We also need to consider how to make better use of existing funding and instruments like the infrastructure levy. The UK Committee on Climate Change has advised that we must also consider changes in tax policy. The Scottish National Investment Bank also has a key role to play.One low cost and high impact measure that could unlock a whole range of new conservation opportunities would be for the next Scottish Budget to kick start a new Conservation Finance Fund with initial public seed investment to help lever in private finance. This would build on the collaborative work led by SEPA and the Scottish Wildle Trust on the ldquoRoute Map to pound Billionrsquo.If the necessary public and private funding is forthcoming, then the Scottish Governmentrsquos proposed partnership approach and the desire to involve communities much more in decision making is also key to success. However, we must ensure that communities and NGOs are engaged on an equal footing with business. We look forward to working with government to make this a truly green and transformational recovery that enhances all aspects of our wellbeing.Dougie Peedle is Head of Policy, Scottish Wildle Trust

title: wwe-superstar-drew-mcintyre-dream-match-vs-rock-ibrox-bittersweet-behind-closed-doors-wrestlemania
story: The Ayrshire native can finally lay claim to the moniker of WWErsquos top superstar after winning their flagship championship belt back in April at a somewhat unusual behind closed doors WrestleMania pay-per-view. McIntyre, , defeated then-title holder and legitimate UFC star Brock Lesnar within a few short minutes to secure his place in history as the UKrsquos first WWE champ.But it was with a tinge of regret. An ounce of disappointment that he wasnrsquot stepping out in front of the usual packed , fans due to the Covid pandemic. Admittedly, the brawler says, his sadness quickly subsided. For better or worse, this yearrsquos WrestleMania was bound to be memorable.ldquoItrsquos not what I imagined or what I dreamt of, he told Glasgow Times. ldquoIt was supposed to be at Raymond James Stadium in front of , people, literally  minutes from my home [in Florida]. The main event against Brock Lesnar for the WWE title, it couldnrsquot have been any more perfect. Then the pandemic hit and I went through all the emotions possible.ldquoItrsquos when I started watching the news and speaking to people about it that I understood how severe the situation was. The fact we were pushing ahead with WrestleMania during dficult times, it changed my mindset. I went from disappointment to thinking I was being a bit selfish. That I could make people smile, it was really big and a feel good story, so it took on a whole new meaning to me. Nobody will forget the WrestleMania when the world stood still.McIntyre has ticked being WWErsquos main champion off his bucket list and now spends his time on Monday Night RAW defending his prize against all-comers. Most recently, at their Extreme Rules PPV, McIntyre retained his gold against former pal Dolph Ziggler - who had a big-name in his corner for support.Wrestling legend-turned Hollywood A-lister Dwayne lsquoThe Rockrsquo Johnson backed McIntyrersquos opponent, leading the Scot to challenge the future Hall of Fame athlete to a dream match via social media. And the lsquoScottish Psychopathrsquo made clear his one request for where and when. ldquoThe Rock is the best, one of the nicest guys in the world and he deserves all his success, McIntyre went on.ldquoThere was a time I was doing nothing, really, and TMZ asked him who he thought was the next breakout star. And he picked me, which really inspired me and fired me up. I appreciated that and it gave me motivation. Then to see WWE posted an image of Dolph Ziggler with the title, and Rock backed him up! That hurt my one feeling Irsquove got left.ldquoI thought, lsquoWhat would Rock do in this situation rsquo If this was  , what would he say  I thought, screw it. Irsquom the champion, I donrsquot back down to anyone, even The Rock. My phone exploded. Irsquod love to face The Rock anywhere, butthere was one place on earth it would be a WrestleMania at Ibrox. That would be great for personal reasons.ldquoIt would probably have to be Hampden, wersquod need somewhere massive. If he chose to come back for a match, as the biggest Box Office attraction in the world, wow. Come on, Rock, give me that match.Watch WWE Champion Drew McIntyre defend his Title at SummerSlam on the WWE Network next Sunday, August rd, with the event also airing on BT Sport Box Office. title: wwe-star-drew-mcintyre-opens-speaking-movement
story: Hundreds of men and women from within the industry took to Twitter and Facebook last month to detail moments - as professionals or fans - where they were taken advantage of by others within the sport. Some allege to have been sexually assaulted while others claim they were abused both physically and emotionally.The rally prompted WWE and other wrestling promotions to suspend and even fire some employees over the allegations. Glasgow-based company Insane Championship Wrestling released a statement amid the movement saying inappropriate conduct is not tolerated. But now WWE champion and Ayr-born McIntyre has given his thoughts on the issue.The -year-old was proud to see so many brave women and men step forward with their stories. And he wants anyone affected to continue using their voice to stamp out any unacceptable behaviour and keep pro-wrestling safe for all. ldquoItrsquos horrible, he told Glasgow Times. ldquoI think in  therersquos been a few dficult conversations that needed to be had. Clearly itrsquos a conversation that had to come up and Irsquom glad it did. In future itrsquos going to kick out a lot of things that shouldnrsquot have been part of wrestling in the first place, everyone is going to be better for it.ldquoI want everyone to be comfortable in the wrestling environment, Irsquom disappointed in a lot of people that we worked so hard to build something and the fact that that was going on was very, very upsetting. Please keep making your voices heard, we want wrestling to be a safe and comfortable place for everyone and it absolutely will be going forward.ldquoThatrsquos the one positive we can take from , that a lot of uncomfortable conversations are happening, but itrsquos all for the good.

title: letters-price-democracy-majority-wishes-ignored
story: Overarching all of this is the denial of justice for the near  per cent of Scots who wanted to keep the Union in  and now find themselves in the minority because SNP spin has made out Nicola Sturgeon is near perfect but Boris Johnson is the exact opposite. This is not true but we are currently experiencing a constant bombardment of the SNPs mantra with little air-time given to the opposition viewpoint.We are in danger of losing our way and having independence foisted upon us with all the rather unpleasant consequences that the SNP, with Green support, are happy to sweep under the carpet. Independence must be demonstrably earned over a long time period, with most of the problems ironed out by a competent government and with the support of the vast majority of Scots and not simply rushed whilst a few polls appear favourable.Keeping Mr Swinney in office is a bad start.Dr Gerald Edwards, Glasgow.I MAKE no comment on the suitability of the current Education Secretary as it is blindingly obvious he has neither the competence nor the stature to hold this or any other post in government.That he is probably no worse than the majority of other ministers, especially health, says all there needs to be said about this administration ... I except the First Minister purely on her personality and presentation skills.However my anger at the moment is reserved fully for the Greens, whose votes kept Mr Swinney in situ by voting against the no confidence motion earlier today.The Greens do the whole country, especially our young people, a disservice and one would hope that come the election voters will demonstrate their contempt for a party that is currently a disgrace to politics.James Martin, Bearsden.I FOUND Andy Maciverrsquos latest articlesomewhat adversely affected by non sequitur. Early in the piece he writes "I have found the SNP in government to be reliable and competent" and he embellishes that by adding it has "managed the country perfectly well". Reading that, I wondered what parallel universe I have been living in since .Later in the same article, he touches upon the SNP Governmentrsquos record and mentions only a few areas where it has fallen short and concedes that "we are not the envy of the world". One could fairly regard that conclusion as putting it mildly. In one of her responses to Ruth Davidson at Holyrood this week Nicola Sturgeon said that the SNP record would be on the line next May. It is dficult to argue against that. Yes, let the people decide.Ian W Thomson, Lenzie.ITS just so dficult to draw a metaphorical bead on Andy Maciver when hes in discursive mood on Scotlands ills.First, he draws a negative picture of Scotlands schools which I as a parent and grandparent simply do not recognise. Secondly, he produces a set of statistics which accurately show how far the UKs NHS is falling behind its OECD equivalents, and somehow implies that the Scottish Government is equally responsible for that. But then, just when I think I can pull the trigger, he comes up with this gem: "So herersquos one idea. The Scottish Government should create a small National Renewal Unit. Give them a big travel budget. And let them bring back the best of the rest of the world to prepare us for a post-coronavirus future."Correct, Mr Maciver. Lets do that, lets call it the Scottish Governments Diplomatic Service and let it operate from embassies in the worldrsquos major capitals. Is Mr Maciver beginning to change his erstwhile opinions on independence John Jamieson, Ayr.THE Prime Minister is about to take his ldquowell-earned holiday in Scotland. This despite the pandemic still raging and the country in the worst financial collapse ever known.I would not, however, expect to see him buying a fridge magnet in Burntisland High Street or hear of him hiring a bike in Millport. I may be mistaken, but I would assume his destination will be considerably less public.So can we analyse what we will be missing when he has his two weeks ldquoabroad in Scotland First, the daily photoshoot featuring the hard hat will be off the agenda.Secondly, the withering, dithering, flamboyant speeches will be put on hold.Thirdly, the dynamic decision-making, which can do a -degree turn in a day, will be suspended or maybe not or maybe could be.So how will we cope with such a loss  In Scotland we will be left to the mercy of the First Minister who is so ldquoincompetent she says she doesnrsquot see herself having a holiday.Instead of a holiday she will be forced to continue to manage the pandemic as best she can as well as the hundreds of other problems associated with governing the people of Scotland.George Kay, Burntisland.DESPITE the exam grades fiasco and the Scottish Governmentrsquos disastrous handling of the Covid crisis, Nicola Sturgeon and the SNP are riding high in the opinion polls. Why is this, I ask  The answer is that we have all been deeply brainwashed by Ms Sturgeon and her daily TV broadcasts, lasting more than four months now. Please would someone call Amnesty International Ian Forbes, Glasgow G.THERE is an interesting contrast in apparent attitudes to taking responsibility between Fiona Robertson, Head of SQA and Leslie Evans, boss of our civil service. Ms Robertson has been willing to take the  on her own to defend her agencys position that, unmoderated, this years results would have been unfeasibly higher than the previous years: an attitude for which she courageously offered no apology . Her problem may well be that the model employed was crude in terms of statistical theory and practice, as one of your recent correspondents has helpfully pointed out, but that doesnt take away from the principle thatthe numberslook wrong, they probably are. Criticism of her and her staff should be balanced by that and by recognition that this was never going to be an easy job.Leslie Evans , in contrast, seems to be doing everything possible to avoid recognising that a hash was made of a relatively straightforward disciplinary process, which likely was or should have been set down in the Scottish Governments code of working practices . All this to the extent that anyone with any knowledge of the judicial review process would have backed Alex Salmond for a winner. The inquiry chairman is to be congratulated for demanding clear and personal answers from Ms Evans.Brian Chrystal, Edinburgh EH.JUST who is the Scottish Government  Your reportage of the Holyrood inquiry into the Alex Salmond debacle continually links ldquothe Scottish Government with behaviour likely to obstruct the investigators getting access to facts related to the original botched probe into the alleged behaviour of the former First Minister. However, the name that persistently crops up is that of a civil servant rather than one of a minister or elected or list MSP.I would have thought that a civil servant, as the name implies, is neither a member of nor part of a government but an inidual in a supporting structure charged to carry out the instructions of the sitting executive.It is important in view of the upcoming Scottish elections that there is clarity in just who is not being completely cooperative with the current investigators is it the civil service or is it the SNP administration.David J Crawford, Glasgow G.ROSEMARY Goring says that the Prime Minister is coming to Scotland again because he wants to save the Union . But does he Consider this his parliamentary majority of  must be in danger, judging by his calamitous approval ratings, and the fact that Labour now has a credible leader.So might he not welcome the chance to lose  non-Tory seats before the next General Election, thus improving his chances of winning He may lead the Conservative and Unionist Party, but he has already jettisoned the support of the Northern Ireland Unionist faction, whence comes the "Unionist" part of the party name, with his border in the Irish Sea to finalise the EU withdrawal agreement. Might he find it even easier to let Scotland secede, taking its troublesome non-Tory MPs out of the House of Commons  The six Tories would be collateral damage but a price worth paying.Also, by dint of the border and the dependence of the vast majority of Scottish exports upon English ports, he could still keep Scotland on a tight rein.In the meantime we face the prospect of a disrupted food supply due to the forthcoming Brexit shambles. Could that be why the Prime Minister is suddenly keen on fighting obesity, in the hope that we will accept the resulting shortages, perhaps even rationing, as all part of a national weight-loss strategy It could be that there is method in the Prime Ministers madness after all.Jane Ann Liston, St Andrews.Read more: Swinney survives no confidence vote

title: issue-day-ramsay-street-recasting-far-first
story: So who is being recast If you donrsquot want any spoilers, donrsquot read onhellipotherwise, Australian actor Tim Robards, who plays businessman Pierce Greyson on the show, is departing. He was supposed to film scenes up until September, but has decided to leave early due to changing travel restrictions resulting from the pandemic that make it dficult for him to be at his family home in Sydney where his partner is expecting their first child.Hersquos being replaced The character of Pierce will be played by fellow Australian actor, Don Hany, for the remainder of the storyline on the show that airs in the UK on Channel .Fans are not amused The announcement drew ire on social media, with one viewer writing on Neighboursrsquo Instagram, ldquoThatrsquos the most stupidest thing ever and another adding: ldquoSohellipPierce has had a head swap operation and nobody in Ramsay Street is going to notice  Another commented: ldquoCouldnrsquot you have just written him out  Hate replacements. Look at Ben Mitchell in EastEnders.Ben Mitchell The character of Albert Square stalwart Phil Mitchellrsquos son, Ben, has in fact been played by six dferent actors since being introduced in , with the role currently portrayed by Max Bowden. In fact, the Mitchell family matriarch, Peggy, memorably portrayed by Barbara Windsor from  on-and-off till , was previously played by the late English actress, Jo Warne.Neighbours has done it before Elsewhere in Australia Back in the pre-internet s when UK viewers were still  months or so behind Australian soap opera episodes, Home  Away launched on ITV and one of the key characters, Pippa Fletcher - who was in a pivotal role as a foster mother in the programme - was played by actress Vanessa Downing. In less than two years, though, she quit the role and was replaced by actress Debra Lawrance in a move that startled fans.Dallas The glitzy s US soap recasted at the drop of a Stetson. Of the many roles recast, the most memorable include Ewing matriarch Miss Ellie, played by Barbara Bel Geddes and Donna Reed, and the role of Jenna, which had three actresses over the years, including Morgan Fairchild and Priscilla Presley.As for Ramsay Street The casting move has garnered plenty of headlines and thousands of comments online, so perhaps as PT Barnum said, ldquoTherersquos no such thing as bad publicity.

title: letters-scottish-natural-heritage-need-correction-rather-transformation
story: The term ldquoheritage implies ldquothat which is inherited from past generations, maintained in the present, and bestowed to future generations ndash and ldquoNatureScot has lost all that meaning.The SNH website tells us that ldquousing the Scottish Natural Heritage brand correctly every time lets us communicate better with our audiences and with each other. Our brand is a confident, positive statement, which creates a strong  for all of our communications when used correctly. A professional and consistent approach helps people to recognise our work and put their trust in what we have to say. The CEO, Francesca Osowska, went on to tell us: ldquoWersquove done a lot of research in terms of public opinion surveys, which shows the word heritage is what people latch onto, not natural. So they think our remit is buildings and ancient monuments: theyrsquore important but thatrsquos not what wersquore about. So the public can expect SNH to get a refund from the agency which advised on the last branding  Methinks that this is more likely to be a reflection on the standard of Scottish education.The website goes on to talk atof ldquotransforming how we work. Transforming how we work supports everything we do for all of our outcomes. Why transform how SNH works  I thought that it was the branding that was flawed ndash what was so wrong with what SNH was actually doing  And in the detail for what this transformation will mean, it says:ldquoTransforming how we work involves providing information at the right time to inform decisions about nature. Surely this was being done already ldquoTransforming how we work involves to generate solutions together shared problems. English this is not.ldquoTransforming how we work involves supporting innovation and ersy the funding for nature. Surely ldquoersying  What might ldquoersying the funding for nature mean in practice ldquoTransforming how we work involves being the change we want to see by being more flexible and leading by example. Understandable this is not.And we also discover that SNH employs a ldquoDirector of People and Nature. A ldquoDirector of Nature ndash oh, what power. Surely this is all it needshellipIn the same edition of the paper, I was amused to notice the abbreviation for BT Murrayfield, and I realised that SNH now appears to be an agency which doesnrsquot know its BTM from its elbow. That is, happy to pay for second-rate advice yet incapable of recognising it as such, but capable somehow of forecasting that the ldquometamorphosis will see the organisation sharpen the nationrsquos focus on nature. It seems to have no conception of the ldquoeffect on the nation that it has already achieved, never mind its future impact.Peter Fraser, Aberdeen AB.GOOD GRIEFALTHOUGH I understand that, over time, languages will evolve, I share Irene Conways despairat the deterioration in spoken and written English .One of my bugbears is that, when an inidual is asked "How are you ", the response, more often than not, will be "Im good." No-one has questioned their degree of piety, but their well-being.Brian Johnston, Torrance.I SHARE Irene Conways despair anent the deterioration in spoken and written English.I fear, however, that Ms Conway has erred in her use of the word "latter" when she writes of the words " fair", " fare" and " fayre". "Latter" should be used when comparing or referring to no more than two words.More power, however, to Ms Conways elbow.David Miller, Milngavie.THOSE TORMENTING JOYSHAVING listened for more than two hours the other day to the sound of doves cooing in the trees I consulted my favourite English usage bookand looked up onomatopoeia and found this example from Tennyson. "The moan of doves in immemorial elms And murmuring of innumerable bees". Mmm, lovely. Just what I had heard, so it was interesting to see David Millers letter on social distancingand the oxymoron thus produced in those two words.One of the examples of an oxymoron in my book is the placing of "a carefully careless scarf", but because it echoes my own intense dislike of mobile phones and other small devices, which are playing a massive part in the daily le of this planet, I prefer to think of Milton and his "precious bane" . The authors of the book mention that "someone had neatly combined the contrarieties of the telephone as a boon and curse, using Miltons words, "O, precious bane Tormenting joy Dividing chain Exacting toy".Too true, when you really think about it.Thelma Edwards, Kelso.

title: five-must-read-scottish-books-headed-tv-film
story: ConvictionSpeaking of Witherspoon, she chose Conviction by Denise Mina as her Hello Sunshine Book Club pick last December. Although no film deal has been formally announced, theres a good chance that the actor and producer has an eye on bringing the whip-smart thriller ndash where a woman obsessed with true crime podcasts finds herself at the heart of a jet-setting murder mystery ndash to the screen. In , Minas Paddy Meehan crime novels were adapted to become The Field of Blood, starring Jayd Johnson, David Morrissey and Peter Capaldi, which ran for two series. Her new novel, The Less Dead, is published on Thursday.:Summer Reads : The  best beach and holiday booksA Dark MatterDoug Johnstonersquos domestic noir series centres on three generations of women ndash Jenny Skelf, her mother Dorothy and daughter Hannah ndash who run a family funeral director business with a sideline as private investigators in Edinburgh. The first novel, A Dark Matter, was published in January and has been optioned as a TV drama by Glasgow-based production company Blazing Grfin, while the second, The Big Chill, is due out on Thursday. Click here to read The Herald Magazine cover story with the author.Blood OrangeThis brilliant debut novel from Harriet Tyce has been optioned by World Productions ndash the makers of Line of Duty and Bodyguard ndash for development into a TV series. title: property-patter-give-home-facelift-budget---living-room-bedroom
story: But in part  of our lsquoHow to give your home a facelt on a budgetrsquo, wersquore going to give you some great ideas to update your bedrooms, living room and even hallway.BedroomsWhen it comes to styling your bedroom, the best way to inject some colour and style, whilst keeping costs down, is to add it through your accessories. Keep your wall colours neutral, like white and grey, but use your curtains, bedding and cushions to inject splashes of colour.Buying new bedding and hanging a new set of curtains can cost a lot less than a few tins of paint once you factor in all the rollers and brushes yoursquoll need to buy, plus it will take less time too.Once yoursquove bought the cushions, next time yoursquore thinking about changing the colour, just buy new covers and match the size of the cushions. That means you can store the others away, pass them on to a friend or use them in another room.Donrsquot forget about artwork. You can find some really trendy prints online and IKEA is great for cheap frames too. Make sure you buy the same size prints each time, meaning you can keep the same frames. You can update the frames easily too with a cheap can of spray paint.Canrsquot afford a new carpet  Yoursquoll be amazed at what a good deep clean and adding a colourful or patterned rug can do.If your furniture is looking a bit tired, upcycle with a lick of paint and new door handles. You can pick up a tin of furniture paint from most hardware stores or online and you can buy cute, quirky doorknobs from eBay or Etsy, or even just try spray painting the existing ones.Metal accessories like curtain rods and light fittings can benefit from that spray paint too!Upcycling is a great way to keep costs low, give a much loved item a new lease of le and is good for the environment by cutting out waste.Living roomMoving on to the most used room in the house, this can be the most dficult to update as it no doubt has many uses. From the TV room to the playroom to the dining room, your living space probably needs to be more practical than anything . But you can still add some style along the way.Your sofa likely dominates the room and can be the most expensive piece in the room ndash with the exception of the TV! So replacing this often can be costly. But have you considered replacing the covers  If your sofa is in generally good condition but itrsquos looking a bit off-colour, you can buy covers that fit over the top.IKEA do a range of these covers that are made for their sofa ranges, but you can find places online that offer made to measure services. This can be more expensive, but definitely cheaper than buying a whole new sofa and are machine washable! Alternatively, adding a new throw and some scatter cushions can have the same effect.Many of the tips for the bedroom can be used in the living room too. Like adding a nice feature wall for a splash of colour or why not try adding a nice gallery wall with lots of family pictures  A great way to add a personal touch to a room. You can even get the family involved to pick out their favourite pictures.Plants are a great way to brighten up a room and fill any unused corners. Donrsquot worry, it doesnrsquot mean another mouth to feed, there are plenty of really great looking fake ones to buy.Have you tried shopping from other rooms in your house  Yoursquod be surprised at how much you can change your rooms by simply swapping the accessories about.HallwayTherersquos nothing nicer than a warm welcome so donrsquot forget your hallway when yoursquore giving your home a makeover.If itrsquos on the small size then good advice is to keep it nice and bright to give the illusion of space and add colour by adding some prints to the wall, some useful hanging hooks and even a funky doormat.Everything in your hallway needs to have a practical use, but that doesnrsquot mean it has to be boring.You can add plants here too butyoursquore limited on floor space, why not try some hanging baskets or small potted plants on shelves.Maybe go the extra mile and paint the doors in your hallway  This trend is becoming more popular, with people opting for painting their doors and skirting boards, from pink to yellow and even black.Hopefully, these tips have given you some DIY inspiration to give your home a little low-cost makeover.

title: Women from Salmond trial give first TV interviews to BBC  What do they say
story: Another said hearing the verdicts was ldquolike being punched in the stomach.The interviews are at the centre of a new BBC documentary, The Trial Of Alex Salmond, to be shown on Monday.On Tuesday, the first witnesses appear before the Scottish Parliament inquiry into the Scottish Governmentrsquos handling of complaints against Mr Salmond by two women civil servants.In March this year Mr Salmond was acquitted at the High Court in Edinburgh of  charges of sexual assault brought by nine women. Three of those women, their identities concealed and their words spoken by actors, appear in the programme.The hour-long film presented by Kirsty Wark also includes a claim by SNP MP Kenny MacAskill that some evidence before the court was ldquoentirely . And BBC Scotland Editor Sarah Smith is seen describing Mr Salmond as a ldquoreally diminished figure.: Poll compares Alex Salmond Boris Johnson popularityWark calls the proceedings at the High Court in Edinburgh in March the UKrsquos first ldquoMe Too trial. ldquoIt is about peoplersquos lives and the way women and men treat each other, she says.One of the women tells the Newsnight presenter of her reluctance to come forward.ldquoI didnrsquot want to be a story.
